description: From Dutch klomp (“clump, mass, wooden shoe”), from Old Dutch *klumpo, from Proto-Germanic *klumpô (“clump, lump, mass; clasp”), from Proto-Indo-European *glembʰ- (“clamp, mass”).

entries.meaning: The sound of feet hitting the ground loudly.

verbs.description: clomp (third-person singular simple present clomps, present participle clomping, simple past and past participle clomped)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To walk heavily or clumsily, as with clogs.
(transitive) To make some object hit something, thereby producing a clomping sound.
